nodes.label: Fastest code is code that doesn't exist
Use tools that work / prefer stability

nodes.title: Agent audit and maintenance decisions v0

summary.high_level: Records resolved maintenance policy choices from the audit loop, including index update mode and first vision-alignment KPI anchor.
Designed a standalone CLI tool (sb) to handle scene and session commits, JSON validation, and index rebuilding. Establishes minimal 3-capability commit agent contract.
key_decisions: Use standalone CLI (not embedded in Codex or project repo).
Agent contract limited to grounding (read), commit (write), and index/validation (maintain).
Projects remain structured locally; second-brain references them via Project Map scenes.
Adopt Intake → Draft → Publish conceptual pipeline for future automation.
summary.architectural_shift: Transition from structured-manual workflow to automatable commit-layer infrastructure.

nodes.label: Four principles that separate successful AI builders (second brain case study)

summary.high_level: Defines a repeatable agent-operated session loop: ground context, execute constrained tasks, close out with strict contract, and feed audit metrics back into planning.
Indexes Kalshi pipeline session artifacts and preserves the handoff context toward Phase 9 planning.
Defines canonical project ID policy for second-brain core and deprecates legacy alias IDs while preserving historical artifacts.

nodes.title: Prompt workflow inventory for session lifecycle

summary.high_level: Maps prompt files used to start and close sessions, including Kalshi-focused closure prompts and schema-driven archive prompts.

nodes.title: Second-brain commit and index toolchain map

summary.high_level: Maps the concrete local tooling that commits session artifacts and maintains index files.
Defines structure and maintenance rules for sessions/<tool>/index.json files.

nodes.label: Spec Spec v0
nodes.description: Higher-order spec from which all other specs derive. Defines required sections, governance invariants, naming, versioning, and status lifecycle.

summary.high_level: Tracks first-order vision-alignment KPI for session closure quality and principle-link discipline.

nodes.title: Operational workflow model for second-brain sessions

summary.high_level: Formalized the working workflow into a disciplined operational model. Clarified that sessions are state transitions, artifacts are durable state snapshots, and resumption is deterministic rehydration.
key_points: Work must always attach to a project ID.
Sessions operate under explicit principle constraints.
Patterns provide structural bias and prevent architectural drift.
Every meaningful session must emit a structured artifact.
Artifacts encode decisions, deltas, and open questions.
Resumption loads prior state instead of restarting from memory.

summary.high_level: Refined understanding of the working workflow. Clarified that sessions function as state transitions in a cognitive state machine. Artifacts act as durable state snapshots enabling deterministic re-entry and agent replay.
summary.core_insight: The second brain is not a note system; it is a state machine for cognition. Each session represents a transition from State_n to State_n+1. Artifacts encode the transition.

nodes.label: Session archiver prompt template (filled schema copy)
base -> delta -> materialized lineage
nodes.description: Core derivation chain: a base prompt is transformed by ordered deltas into a materialized output with full replay metadata.

nodes.label: Commit agent contract (3-capability model)
nodes.definition: Minimal agent interface: grounding access (read project docs), commit access (write scenes/session artifacts), and maintenance access (reindex + validate).

nodes.label: Deterministic materialization
nodes.description: Same base + same ordered deltas must produce byte-identical output. Delta order: ascending numeric order, tie-break by id lexical order.

nodes.label: Kalshi Phase 9 handoff state
nodes.definition: State reached after Phase 8 closeout where Phase 9 scope, thresholds, and challenger policy-readiness criteria must be defined.

nodes.label: principle_linked_artifact_pct
nodes.definition: Percent of non-trivial session artifacts linked to at least one canonical principle.

nodes.label: Project ID alias map
nodes.definition: Alias resolution map for project IDs. New links must use canonical IDs; legacy references remain valid for historical truth.

nodes.label: Project map grounding model
nodes.definition: Graph node defining repo location, canonical documents, and grounding order for agents before reasoning about a project.

nodes.label: PromptArtifact
nodes.description: Canonical prompt content unit (base or materialized). Required fields: id, type, title, content, version, status.

nodes.label: PromptDelta
nodes.description: Incremental transformation over a base prompt. Required fields: id, delta_type, patch, order, version, status.

nodes.label: Prompt-driven session closure
nodes.definition: Reusable prompts encode the required output contract so session closeout artifacts remain consistent and machine-parseable.

nodes.label: PromptMaterializationRun
nodes.description: Deterministic replay execution record. Required fields: id, base_prompt_id, applied_delta_ids[], output_prompt_id, generated_on.

nodes.label: PromptVariant
nodes.description: Named target variant for tool/context/domain specialization. Required fields: id, target_context, version, status.

nodes.label: Session index object schema
nodes.definition: Each sessions/<tool>/index.json file is a JSON object with fields: tool, artifacts[], last_updated.

nodes.label: Session index maintenance
nodes.definition: Keep sessions/<tool>/index.json synchronized with artifact IDs present in each sessions/<tool>/ directory.

nodes.label: Session index rebuild rule
nodes.definition: Index entries are derived from sessions/<tool>/*.json excluding index.json, producing artifacts[] records with id/date/resumption_score/summary_snippet.

nodes.label: Session index update policy
nodes.definition: On successful closeout, update sessions/<tool>/index.json automatically by default. Use --no-index only for bulk backfill, rollback, or controlled migration runs.

nodes.label: Spec
nodes.description: A versioned governance document with required sections: Title, Version, Status, Inputs, Purpose, Scope, Core Definitions, Determinism & Drift Tests, Governance Rules, Failure Modes, Success Criteria, Immediate Next Step.

nodes.label: Allowed spec status values
nodes.description: Allowed values: Experimental, Stable, Deprecated.

nodes.label: Spec derivation
nodes.description: Every spec is a concretion of the Spec Spec. Child specs must include all required sections and satisfy inherited governance invariants.

nodes.label: Spec filename pattern
nodes.description: Filename regex for spec artifacts: ^[A-Z][A-Z_]*_SPEC_v[0-9]+\.md$.

nodes.label: Spec required sections in canonical order
nodes.description: Canonical order: 1) Title, 2) Version, 3) Status, 4) Inputs, 5) Purpose, 6) Scope, 7) Core Definitions, 8) Determinism & Drift Tests, 9) Governance Rules, 10) Failure Modes, 11) Success Criteria (vN), 12) Immediate Next Step.

nodes.label: Spec status lifecycle
nodes.description: Experimental -> Stable -> Deprecated. Experimental allows breaking changes; Stable requires version bumps; Deprecated is read-only.

nodes.label: Spec versioning
nodes.description: Monotonically increasing vN integer per subject. Semantic/governance changes require a bump; editorial fixes do not.

nodes.label: Spec version string pattern
nodes.description: Version field must match pattern ^v[0-9]+$.

nodes.label: Vision-alignment anchor KPI
nodes.definition: principle_linked_artifact_pct = percent of non-trivial artifacts with at least one canonical principle link.

nodes.label: Workflow as cognitive state machine
nodes.definition: A model in which each session transitions a project from one defined cognitive state to another, with structured artifacts capturing the delta.

nodes.label: Zero-shot resumption bundle
nodes.definition: Minimal context load set for cold-start execution: core project scene + latest taxonomy + top 3 recent artifacts by resumption score.

nodes.label: Ontology: Finding Meaning in Data (Palantir RFx Blog Series #1)
nodes.summary: Palantir defines ontology as a semantic layer that maps raw data into real-world objects, relationships, and logic. It decouples data pipelines from applications and embeds meaning, permissions, and operations directly into a shared object model.

nodes.label: Claude computer-use + Obsidian + TypeScript agent on VPS
nodes.description: Claude’s computer-use plus a custom TypeScript agent on a VPS with Obsidian, guided by principle-level architectural best practices.

nodes.label: Dan's Codex + ChatGPT meta-workflow (v1)
nodes.description: Current working pattern where Dan uses Codex and ChatGPT as primary thinking surfaces: Codex for live project work, specs, and pipeline design; ChatGPT for higher-level reflection, summaries, and second-brain architecture thinking. Knowledge currently lives mostly in conversations and ad-hoc notes, with an emerging intention to turn high-value threads into graph-structured artifacts.

capture_points: Codex conversations for active builds (specs, trading pipeline design, ML ideas)
ChatGPT threads for meta-analysis, second brain architecture, and workflow reflection
Occasional external docs/notes (e.g., Neovim config, trading research, YouTube/video transcripts)
storage_today: Local config/code repos (e.g., Neovim, trading infra)
Ad-hoc notes/docs when something feels important
intended_future_storage: Graph-structured knowledge base (principles, patterns, concepts, projects, tools)
Artifacts like this video summary encoded as nodes/edges
Project-scoped state snapshots for resumption and meta-analysis
ai_roles: Spec drafting and refinement partner (Codex + ChatGPT)
Future: graph-aware agent that can traverse principles/patterns/projects and propose changes
human_roles: Define intent and constraints for projects (trading, infra, second brain)
Curate which artifacts become first-class graph nodes
Decide when to standardize patterns vs leave things experimental
notable_characteristics: Session-based interactions with Codex tied to concrete work (coding, specs, trading pipeline design)
Higher-level, cross-project reflection done in separate meta threads with ChatGPT
Growing preference for principled, architecture-first thinking over tool-first setups
Explicit interest in resilience to tool churn and context-window limits

nodes.label: Discord + Obsidian + MacWhisper capture stack
nodes.description: Discord as capture surface, MacWhisper for local transcription, and Obsidian for storage; slash commands trigger processing and filing by project.

nodes.label: Prompt lineage drift tests
nodes.description: Four invariance tests: repeat-run stability, permutation invariance, supersession stability, missing-delta failure.

nodes.label: Hyperfast agent session loop
nodes.description: Ground -> Execute -> Validate -> Closeout -> Reindex -> Audit -> Plan.

nodes.label: Meta-agent framework orchestrating multiple coding assistants
nodes.description: A meta-agent coordinating Claude Code, Codex, Copilot, and Goose using a writer–critic loop, capable of setting up infra and generating UIs.

nodes.label: Notion mobile capture + scheduled Claude processing
nodes.description: Notion mobile export as capture mechanism, with Claude periodically processing an inbox and sorting into structured views.

nodes.label: Notion + Zapier + Claude/ChatGPT second brain stack
nodes.description: Capture and route notes using Notion for storage, Zapier for automation, and Claude or ChatGPT as the intelligence layer.

nodes.label: Postgres + vector DB + graph DB as second brain infrastructure
nodes.description: Hybrid database system: Postgres for structured data, vector DB for semantic search, and Neo4j for relationships, exposed via API/SDK.

nodes.label: Prompt ID naming convention
nodes.description: Prompt IDs: prompt/<domain>_<purpose>_vN. Delta IDs: prompt_delta/<base>_<order>_<intent>_vN. Materialized IDs: prompt/<base>__<variant>_vN.

nodes.label: Session → Artifact → Resumption loop
nodes.description: A disciplined loop where sessions begin with declared constraints, end with structured artifacts, and future sessions resume from those artifacts.

nodes.label: Session → Artifact → Resumption loop
nodes.description: Each work session emits a structured artifact capturing decisions, changes, and open questions. Future sessions begin by rehydrating from that artifact.

nodes.label: Slack capture + local YAML + Claude Code session-based processing
nodes.description: Slack as capture, local YAML files as storage, and Claude Code sessions that process inbox items, classify them, and write YAML on demand.

nodes.label: Child spec derivation contract
nodes.description: Child spec must include all required sections, follow filename/version/status constraints, inherit governance invariants, and only add domain-specific sections in optional placement.

nodes.label: Spec drift test suite
nodes.description: Minimum checks: repeat-run stability, required-section completeness, filename regex conformance, and deterministic rendering from structured form.

nodes.label: Spec naming convention
nodes.description: <SCOPE>_<SUBJECT>_SPEC_vN.md — uppercase scope, optional subject, version integer.

nodes.label: Optional spec sections
nodes.description: Optional sections: Architecture and Cross-Artifact Constraints. If present, place them between Scope and Determinism & Drift Tests.

nodes.label: 12 required spec sections
nodes.description: Title, Version, Status, Inputs, Purpose, Scope, Core Definitions, Determinism & Drift Tests, Governance Rules, Failure Modes, Success Criteria, Immediate Next Step.

nodes.label: Standalone CLI commit pattern
nodes.description: A local-first command-line tool that writes scene/session JSON, validates structure, and maintains indexes without requiring database infrastructure.

nodes.label: Zapier Slack → Claude → Notion classification flow
nodes.description: Slack messages trigger a Zapier flow that calls Claude for JSON classification, cleans/parses results, routes to Notion DBs, logs inbox entries, and replies in Slack.

nodes.label: If the agent builds it, the agent can maintain it
Architecture is portable, tools are not
No in-place semantic mutation of historical prompts
Principles-based guidance scales better than rules
Your system can be infrastructure, not just a tool
Kalshi 15m BTC Pipeline
nodes.purpose: Reliable, reproducible, and auditable pipeline for ingesting, normalizing, and validating Kalshi BTC 15-minute market data.
notes_for_agents: Treat README as the entrypoint for intent + commands.
Treat PLAN as the canonical roadmap / planning truth.
Treat OPEN_QUESTIONS as the canonical unresolved decision space.
Treat AGENTS as durable workflow + execution rules.
Use checkpoints as milestone snapshots; use specs for architecture contracts; use reports for results.

nodes.label: Agent Ontology
nodes.summary: A minimal, practical ontology for LLM-powered agents: what exists in the agent's world model, how it plans, acts, remembers, and learns.

nodes.label: ChatGPT (meta-reflection + architecture)
nodes.description: ChatGPT used primarily for higher-level reflection, second-brain architecture, and workflow/meta-analysis separate from day-to-day execution.

nodes.label: Codex (project + spec environment)
nodes.description: Codex environment where Dan runs active builds, specs, and pipeline design work, often in longer-running threads focused on specific projects.

nodes.label: Second-brain CLI (sb)
nodes.description: Local CLI for committing scenes/sessions, validating JSON, and rebuilding session indexes.

nodes.label: Session index updater script
nodes.description: Script that scans sessions directories and updates per-tool index.json files.

edges.description: A delta transforms a base PromptArtifact.
A delta specializes toward a named variant.
A run produces a materialized PromptArtifact from base + deltas.
